title: R43912
content: In the legislative process, bills and joint resolutions can become law, while simple and concurrent resolutions are used for internal matters or to express sentiment. In the 113th Congress, 943 pieces of legislation received floor action in the House, with approximately 73% being bills or joint resolutions and 27% being simple or concurrent resolutions. Of these, 846 originated in the House and 97 in the Senate. In the 113th Congress, the House considered more legislation sponsored by majority party Members. 74% of all measures receiving initial House floor action were sponsored by Republicans, while 27% were sponsored by Democrats. The ratio of majority to minority party sponsorship varied based on the parliamentary procedure used. In the 113th Congress, the House considered more legislation sponsored by majority party Members. 74% of all measures receiving initial House floor action were sponsored by Republicans, while 27% were sponsored by Democrats. Measures introduced under the Suspension of the Rules procedure were sponsored by Republicans (32%), Democrats (32%), and political independents (less than 1%). The House generally uses the Suspension of the Rules procedure for non-controversial measures with bipartisan support. During the 113th Congress, the House considered legislation with majority party Members sponsoring most measures. The breakdown in party sponsorship for measures brought up by unanimous consent was uneven. The House used various parliamentary mechanisms to bring legislation to the floor, including privileged business like appropriations measures. During the 113th Congress, the House primarily used special rules to consider legislation, including appropriations measures. In recent Congresses, most legislation was brought up using the Suspension of the Rules procedure, which allows for quick action on bills with widespread support. This procedure includes a 40-minute debate limit, no floor amendments, and a two-thirds majority requirement. During the 112th and 113th Congresses, the House implemented additional policies for the Suspension of the Rules procedure, limiting its use for certain legislation and requiring measures to be available for three days prior to consideration. These policies continued in force, with 59% of legislation receiving House floor action in the 113th Congress. In the 113th Congress, 59% of legislation receiving House floor action was brought up using the Suspension of the Rules procedure, with 90% originating in the House and 10% in the Senate. Certain types of legislation were placed in a "privileged" category, allowing them to be called up for consideration. This included Order of Business Resolutions and procedural resolutions reported by the House Committee on Rules. Order of Business Resolutions, Committee Assignment Resolutions, Correcting Enrollments, and Providing for Adjournment are privileged resolutions in the House of Representatives. Special rules, committee assignments, enrollment corrections, and adjournment resolutions are all important procedural matters that are given priority consideration. Certain resolutions in the House of Representatives, such as those related to privileges, bereavement, and house organization, are considered privileged and given priority consideration. In the House of Representatives, certain resolutions related to privileges, bereavement, and house organization are considered privileged and given priority consideration. In the 113th Congress, 174 non-lawmaking resolutions were brought before the House as "privileged business," with special orders of business and resolutions assigning Representatives to committees being the most common types. Special rules, also known as "order of business resolutions," enable the House to consider specific legislation by establishing terms for its debate, amendments, and points of order. The Committee on Rules has jurisdiction over these resolutions, which are brought before the House for consideration. While only a small percentage of legislation is brought up via special rule, most significant, complicated, or controversial measures follow this process. In the 113th Congress, 148 measures were considered in this manner. In the 113th Congress, 148 measures were brought before the House under special rules, with 93% being bills or joint resolutions and 7% simple or concurrent resolutions. 20% of lawmaking legislation came up by special rule. Majority party Members sponsored almost all measures considered under special rules, with only 2% originating from the Senate. Legislation is sometimes brought before the House by unanimous consent. In the 113th Congress, 7% of legislation identified by LIS received House floor action through unanimous consent. 51% were bills or joint resolutions, and 49% were simple or concurrent resolutions. 5% of lawmaking legislation came up by unanimous consent. During the 113th Congress, 63% of measures considered by unanimous consent originated in the House. Private bills apply to specific individuals, corporations, or institutions and are placed on a special Private Calendar for consideration. Private bills are brought before the House on the first and third Tuesday of a month under the "House as in Committee of the Whole" procedures. During the 113th Congress, private bills were considered under the "House as in Committee of the Whole" procedures, allowing for debate and amendment under the five-minute rule. However, in practice, these bills were usually passed without debate or record vote. Special parliamentary procedures were established by the House of Representatives for legislation related to the District of Columbia, discharge processes triggered by a petition signed by a majority of the House, and the Calendar Wednesday procedure. These procedures were rarely used in the 113th Congress, with no legislation brought before the House using these mechanisms.
